pros:
Great work-life balance as many IBMers are family-oriented and the work is not demanding like a startup. Opportunities to brainstorm and file patents. 
Teams like the design studio, mobile innovation lab, or security have challenging and fun work/culture, but most of Austin IBM working on the chip/cloud is lowkey energy and monotomous without challenging work. 
The reputation of IBM goes a long way on the resume. 
Paid conference trips if you present or help with the booth.
cons:
Potential stagnation of career due to legacy technology and prioritization of stability over innovation. Most teams lack the zest and drive you'll find in small engineering teams at startups. 
Austin 9xx and 045 offices are drab and are unpleasant to work in.

review_title: Great place to find continuous challenge and new opportunities
pros:
Big enough to provide opportunity and challenge for many and diverse individuals - as long as you are driven and are signed up to the company strategic direction.
Excellent opportunities for enthusiastic early professionals. Learning and management programmes for trainees, interns, apprentices and graduates alike. If you are good at networking and don't mind long hours at times, have a passion for business and technology, then IBM is as good a place as any.
The employee tech platforms are second to none - we have apps, tools, reporting, AI, learning and other enablement at our fingertips. This supports our every day working practice as well as how we manage, plan and learn.
Constant change.
cons:
It's competitive and strategic skills change often so you have to keep learning to stay on top.
Not all salaries are competitive - but could be improving.
If you're not good at making internal connections, the competition for recognition can be a challenge.
Constant change.

Unfortunately reversing processes bumps into a rigid system, so inquire, think and negotiate super profoundly prior to signing up for anything. Do not assume, dare to ask!

Leave this place before it destroys your soul!

review_title: Make sure you're progressing your career rather than IBM taking you for what it needs
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in London, England
pros:
- There are great educational programmes in leadership, coaching and technical development
- There are really smart people working in the company.
- When you're working with great people they are the reason you stay.
- In some roles you have the ability to shape the role and try out new things that excite you.
cons:
- Salary is below average for the industry, the only way to get on a good salary is through negotiation at hire and after that through promotion of band.
- Very much the in-boys having the power, locking everyone else out
- Management take a view of people being able to switched from one technology stack to another without any thought given to the skills people have been building in cutting edge areas that are very beneficial to the company
- Senior leaders are not able to stand up and have the difficult conversations and truly transform the company. They are too scared even when all of their team are telling them what needs to be said.
- There are so many times there are elephants in the room scenarios and management don't tackle them. There is a serious lack of leadership
- Management expect employees to have no lives and work crazy hours, time and time again.
- Nothing is being done around mental health and employee well being, employees are just meant to deal with their issues without any help even when it's called for.
 - Executives come out with big initiatives without any care for how it's done, causing their teams so much stress on how to execute. There is no vision.
- There is no long terms planning and trying to see what's coming down the line.
- The company is very bureaucratic making it very difficult to get things done.
- It's very difficult to make big changes, there is push back at every turn.
- It's difficult to have the autonomy to drive things forward,

job_title: Advisory Software Engineer in Research Triangle Park, NC
pros:
The people actually producing goods (software/hardware/services) are generally good. Benefits and salary are decent and are comparable to other big technology companies. The company has good controls for legal and accounting purposes (Sarbanes Oxley, GDPR, export compliance, etc.) My experience is that IBM is 
conscientious about equal opportunity for all and their facilities are ADA compliant.
cons:
Too many levels of management and those who support management.
Depending upon division, role, manager, etc, your work-life balance may 
be all work and no life. The corporate intranet is a mess, the search engine for said intranet is all but useless. Management moved everyone from cubicles to shared open-space just in time for SARS-COV2, all done in the name of "collaboration" when the reality is its about packing more people into a smaller space to save money. I've averaged getting a new manager every 18 months, there is often little/no knowledge transfer between managers and you have to train each new manager about what your role is.

review_title: Great Opportunity for Growth and Learning
pros:
I've been in IBM for many years with the opportunity to move into various technical and leadership roles as my skills and personal interests matured and changed.
And IBM provides access to and highly encourages continuous education and skills development through both self-paced learning and on-the-job experiences allowing me to continuously explore and grow my personal skills and interests.
cons: While IBM is a big company, the size can be daunting. I suggest focusing on an area of expertise and a single unit within IBM to learn and mature that skill and expertise. Gradually look for opportunities to collaborate with other skills / units and gradually grow your skill and networks in this way. This approach worked very well for me!
